sub_topic: Finding the integral of a trigonometric function
message_1: Find the integral of the function f(x)=5sin(x)+2cos(x)dx.
message_2:
To find the integral of the function f(x) = 5sin(x) + 2cos(x) dx, we will integrate each term separately.

∫[5sin(x) + 2cos(x)] dx = ∫5sin(x) dx + ∫2cos(x) dx

Now, we know that the integral of sin(x) is -cos(x) and the integral of cos(x) is sin(x). So, we have:

∫5sin(x) dx = 5∫sin(x) dx = 5(-cos(x)) = -5cos(x)
∫2cos(x) dx = 2∫cos(x) dx = 2sin(x)

Now, we can combine these results:

∫[5sin(x) + 2cos(x)] dx = -5cos(x) + 2sin(x) + C

where C is the constant of integration.
